caption: The equestrian statue is of Henry IV (who built Pont Neuf ) and just a small plaque is dedicated to DeMolay. Some sources say DeMolay was burnt to death at the nearby Place Dauphine but there is no plaque or monument there.
A beautiful place, but I expected more due to the great story in this place.
Equestrian monument has nothing in common with this one. It is only a small commemorative plate marking the place.
Nice view at the Seine and a possibility to enter the small park on the island Île de la Cité.
Small plaque to a very prominent person in History.
Disappointing considering the history behind it. The gran master killed by the pope and the french king
A sacred spot for Templar Knights and a must-see for Templars and Brother Masons.
As a member of the Order I was humbled to stand in the spot of his death
Nice and quiet place
Nice place and history

“Jacques de Molay, you are avenged!”... but your pyre would undoubtedly deserve a little more than this simple commemorative plaque. The place, backed by the Square du Vert Galant, is an unexpected haven of peace in the middle of the Seine.

Magical place for those like me who love the order of the "Poor Comrades of Christ and the Temple of Solomon" or simply of the "Knights Templar". The stele with reference to the story of the death of the Grand Master (Jacques De Molay) is also good. The only flaw is the fact that it is located very far away and almost invisible to the visitor, who if he doesn't turn around once he comes down the ladder, he won't see it at all.
Nice place for history buffs
It is worth visiting this area of ​​the island since there is a great view of the Seine.

For Lovers of “French History”. And for all people who would like to pay their respects at the memorial of the Grand Master of the Order of the Templar Jacques De Molay. Who knew how to remain silent to defend these Brothers. The Grand Master who demonstrated that silence is a force. The question we can ask ourselves: Did he really succeed in invoking the curse of the King of France Philippe Le Bel and these Three children where walled in silence, the Order pursued its will on the Kings of France over several generations... The statue of King Henry IV is nothing like the Jacques De Molay Memorial. The name mentioned "The Cursed Kings" was carried by the novelist "Maurice Druon".

Jacques de Moley...the last Grand Master of the Templars! Anyone who has even a little interest in the history of the Templars should make a pilgrimage and commemorate here. Executed on March 18, 1314 on the orders of King Philip IV of France with the approval of Pope Clement V. Ultimately the complete destruction of the Order Militum Christi. A simple commemorative plaque and a sign with a brief summary of the facts are all that remains to indicate this. In my opinion, it's a bit low...when you consider the history, influence and community of interests of the Templars. You could do a little more with it here. There are many history buffs...not just because of Dawn Brown! The equestrian statue above...by the way, has nothing to do with the Templars...this only serves as a guide to finding the memorial plaque...follow the stairs down on the back of the statue!
This place to absolutely visit
Faced with this illustrious man, a simple plaque gives the impression that they want us to forget him! "Non nobis dominate, non nobis! Sed domini tua do gloriam!" Long live Jacques De Molay!!!
Memorial dedicated to the last Grand Master of the Order of the Temple, Jacques de Molay, too discreet for my taste for the importance that this Order embodied... Supposed place of his execution.

That is now a park on what was once the place where the last Templar grand master was immolated. The statue of the king does not displace the value of Jaques de Molay's sacrifice, despite only a commemorative plaque and a historical plaque remaining.

It is quite symbolic that there is this memorial to Jacques De Molay in a place as special as the Pont Neuf, the oldest bridge crossing the River Seine in Paris, and characteristic of his tragic death, since it was in that region that he died burned alive . For those who want to visit, however, it can be a little difficult to find. It is necessary to go down the bridge stairs to a garden and then turn around, as the memorial is a small plaque with some words facing the garden. In front of the tribute plaque, there is another plaque, but this time with information about Jacques De Molay.  This beautiful garden, although small, is on the ancient Île aux Juifs, an island where Jacques De Molay was burned. During the construction of the Neuf Bridge centuries later, this island was joined to the Île de la Cité.
Historical place. Especially after reading Druon.
A moving place when you know the story of this great man.
Jack the Molay is not that statue.
Above can be seen. Or poorly indicated.

Unmissable historical place for all Demolay. Memorable!!! It's a shame the board is so small.  The year 1307 saw the beginning of the persecution of the Knights. Jacques DeMolay, along with hundreds of others, were arrested and thrown into dungeons. For seven years, DeMolay and the Knights suffered torture and inhumane conditions.  Plaque marking the place of execution, on the Pont Neuf, in Paris: “In this place, Jacques de Molay, last Grand Master of the Templar Order, was burned, on March 18, 1314”.

Almost lost in the middle of the place, perhaps as something forgotten in people's lives, a small plaque, almost erased, reminds us of the existence or execution of this symbol of loyalty. The place is magical in itself. However, the tribute could be better!!! Definitely worth the visit and the reflection!!! Long live DeMolay!!!

Illustration of the burning of James of Malay and Geoffrey of Charney on March 18, 1314 on the island of Île des Javiaux. (According to old maps there were four islands here) It was said that when James was tied to the stake, he asked to face Notre Dame Cathedral. Probable place of execution the last Grand Masters of the Templar Order, by Inquisitor Guillaume Imbert for heresy on the order of King Philip IV. Interestingly, James, according to legend, cursed King Philip IV and Pope Clement V. The curse was fulfilled and they died within a year.
Currently covered by repairs, but go down the stairs and look to the left before you come down to the park. A new sign is in the works about this horrible event in the early 14th century

There are no memorials. It was originally an independent island, but it was connected to the big island by the new bridge. This is an unknown place. The commemoration of Bartolome's Night is also here. This is a massacre.

The Order of Templar Warrior Monks was very powerful and immensely rich. A state within a state, however they depended on the Pope. Philip the Fair, wishing to destroy them in order to monopolize their fortune, put them on trial with European repercussions, with the approval of the Pope he arrested the knights of the order and they were condemned to death at the stake. Their leader, Grand Master Jacques de Molay, was burned in the city, square du Vert Galant, sending a curse to the king, “Cursed until the 7th generation”. Read the Cursed Kings of Mauritius Druon.

In fact the pyre was held at the dauphine square and so that no one idolized his tomb, King Philippe le Bel made the body of Jaques de Molay disappear. The statue represents Henry IV on horseback. Go down the stairs towards the Jewish island and turn around you will see two sarcophagus-shaped passages. You are there..!!!
An interesting place for those who are passionate about history

The place is interesting for those who have studied information about Jacques De Molay, Philip the Fair, the Order of the Templars, subsequent events, the curse of the Master, the kings cursed by him, the Hundred Years' War, the influence of those events on world history

The Templars forever remained a part of Paris and the history of France, as confirmed by the memorial plaque. For some it will not be anything special, but for others it will be a very important part of their personal Paris.
I visited the monument to Jaques DeMolay and Pont Nuef.
Difficult to find, the equestrian statue of the Master and the plaque are under the new bridge, down a small and hidden stone staircase....
Almost invisible plate. Behind from the staircase from which you go down
